prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the original post is in the wrong. The situation is about a couple living together where the guy pays all the bills because his girlfriend only works part-time. They had an incident where he forgot his wallet and asked her to pay for the takeout, which was under $40. She reacted badly, which upset him. Now he's considering making her start paying some bills because of this one incident.

First, I need to analyze the dynamics here. The guy has been covering all expenses, which he didn't mind until this incident. The key points here are communication, expectations, and fairness. 

The girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she has limited income. The author is now considering making her pay some bills based on a single event. That seems harsh because one incident might not represent her usual attitude. The cost was under $40, which isn't a huge amount, but it's understandable the guy might feel like she should contribute, even if it's just a small part.

However, the way he's reacting might be overreacting. Changing the entire financial arrangement of the relationship because of one incident could be seen as unfair. Also, the girlfriend might not have expected to contribute to the bills if the guy was handling everything before. Maybe they hadn't discussed the financial responsibilities clearly. It's possible that the guy's frustration stems from unmet expectations rather than the incident itself. 

Another angle is the emotional response. The girlfriend's "ugly attitude" and being "put out" might have been due to surprise or not expecting to have to pay. If they hadn't talked about splitting expenses before, then expecting her to pay without prior discussion could be the real issue. The guy might be projecting his own stress or frustration onto her reaction. 

In relationships, communication is key. If the guy was okay with paying everything before, but now it's bothering him, he should talk to her about it instead of punishing her over a single incident. The decision to make her pay bills should come from a mutual agreement, not just one person's frustration. 

So, considering all this, the author might be in the wrong because he's reacting disproportionately to one event and not considering the lack of prior communication. It's important to address the underlying issues rather than taking punitive measures based on a single situation. Therefore, the answer would be A (the author is in the wrong).
